column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) The interviewer asks Strayer, a cognition researcher, about multitasking, focusing on how dual-task interference makes it difficult (even when one or more of the activities is rote), how dangerous it can be (while driving or in medical settings), and how, contrary to popular belief, it causes a net loss of performance since it splits your attention.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Dr. David Strayer's research at the Applied Cognition Laboratory shows that multitasking impairs performance across various settings, from driving while using phones to workplace productivity, as the brain struggles to effectively divide attention between simultaneous cognitive tasks.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) In this discussion, Strayer explains how multitasking often leads to decreased performance and productivity, using examples from driving and office work, and emphasizes that focusing on single tasks can mitigate these effects and enhance overall efficiency.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Researchers at the Applied Cognition Laboratory in Salt Lake City study multitasking and its effects on productivity, finding that attempting to do multiple tasks simultaneously can lead to errors and decreased performance, even for simple tasks like walking and talking.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Multitasking often leads to decreased performance across all tasks involved, particularly in high-stakes situations such as driving or medical procedures, due to competing demands on cognitive resources, while workplace multitasking results in reduced productivity as attention shifts between various software and platforms throughout the day.
#Text=Strayer knows much of what he knows because of the experiments he runs at his Applied Cognition Laboratory in Salt Lake City .
#Text=Often , he measures how people perform one task once they are given a second task .
#Text=We think about multitasking as trying to do two separate , cognitively based tasks at the same time .
#Text=A classic example , one that just about everybody attempts to do , is drive a car and talk on a cell phone .
#Text=We do n’t do that well , and more and more people have these gadgets in the car they bring with them , or the car itself becomes a platform for multitasking , and we do n’t do it well .
#Text=So , it ’s probably a big source for the injuries and fatalities and crashes on the road .

#Text=Now , it would seem obvious — at least to me , maybe I ’m wrong — that not all multitasking is either difficult , and certainly not as dangerous , as driving in a car and trying to do something else that ’s cognitively and / or physically demanding .
#Text=Can you give me some examples of what you see as benign or , in fact , productive multitasking ?
#Text=I would actually just say that even the simplest things , like walking and talking , which you ’d think would be pretty automatic , turn out to be tasks that compete .
#Text=So , if you ’re walking without talking , as soon as you start talking , you ’ll see that the pace of your walk changes , and you may be more likely to trip .
#Text=Anything that is depending on attention to be able to process the world is susceptible to dual - task interference , or problems associated with multitasking .
#Text=A simple example we give is saying the letters of the alphabet : A , B , C , D , E , or counting , one , two , three , four , five .
#Text=Those are easy .
#Text=But if you try and combine them and do something like , A1 , B2 , C3 , D4 , you ’ll quickly find that that becomes difficult , you start to forget where you are .
#Text=And those are two super - well - learned tasks that you can do by themselves .
#Text=But when you try and mix them together , you get all jumbled .
#Text=As soon as you start to multitask , performance on both of the tasks start to degrade .

#Text=Now , how much of that is a function of attempting to multitask versus the fact that we learn habits and patterns and memorize things that become rote , that we do n’t need to engage our cognitive process at all ?
#Text=You can become automatic at certain aspects of performance .
#Text=When your performance is habitual or automatic , it is less dependent on attention .
#Text=So , a lot of things kind of just happen without consciously thinking about them .
#Text=But new things , new activities or new environments , demand you to pay attention , to allocate the prefrontal cortex to process some of that information that ’s new and novel .
#Text=That ’s the real problem , is that if you ’re always in a situation where everything ’s exactly routine , you ’re not stressing the parts of the brain that are responsible for multitasking .
#Text=But as soon as you have some novel activity — like talking , like driving a car , riding a bicycle — you have to pay attention to what you ’re doing .
#Text=You have to engage the prefrontal executive attentional networks .

#Text=Do you know anything , or think much about , multitasking and multitasking failures in other high - stakes settings beyond driving , whether it ’s military decisions or political decisions , business decisions ?
#Text=So we ’ve looked in the medical domain , medical human factors : you can see it in terms of , say , delivery of medicine at a pharmacy .
#Text=If the pharmacist is constantly being interrupted with calls , they ’re going to fill the prescription incorrectly .
#Text=If an anesthesiologist or a surgeon is distracted by the technology in the operating room , that can create a problem .
#Text=In the operating room , it ’s not just the phone , although that ’s sometimes present , but you have all the displays and technology .
#Text=Each one of those are creating alarms that creates this whirl of noise , and alerts and distractions that compete for the anesthesiologist ’s and the surgeon ’s attention .

#Text=So I ’ve been reading about how the modern worker , let ’s say in the U.S. — they could be in marketing , they could be at a nonprofit , could be in finance , whatever — that if you ’re working with a computer , which describes many , many , many , many of us now obviously , that one big change in the last 15 or 20 years is how many pieces of software and how many platforms are — I do n’t want to say fighting for your attention necessarily , that sounds a little a little more pejorative than I mean it to be , but how in the course of your workday , you need to switch and switch and switch and switch .
#Text=We all may have multiple pieces of communication software , multiple pieces of productivity software , and so on .

#Text=Can you talk about that , what seems to be a relatively low - stakes environment — the workplace in a marketing firm or whatever — but how our attention is being carved up during the course of the day ?
#Text=I mean , the research shows that you have a loss of productivity when you ’re trying to multitask — just the opposite of what you think .
#Text=So you may think “ If I ’m multitasking , I ’m going to get a lot more things done . ”
#Text=But what happens is , a big chunk of our day is lost as we ’re switching from one task to the other to the other .

#Text=What they find is that the best way to be productive in the office is to try and focus on one task at a time , focus on just sending that memo out , writing that email , doing whatever that operation is for a short period of time , then take a break and then come back to it .
#Text=Do n’t try and juggle back and forth because you ’ll get confused , you ’ll get lost , you ’ll be this — “ Where was I ? ” kind of switch cost .
